weather_report:
A damp morning has rinsed Crawley, leaving the pavements dark and reflective, the sky a stubborn quilt of grey. By early afternoon the rain is likely lighter and more intermittent at best, with only hesitant bright spells trying to work through. Sun, if it peeks out at all, will be fleeting and soft; the UV is negligible this time of year, and the air feels clean but muted, as though the distance has been pressed closer. It’s a cool, quietly persistent sort of day, more drizzly interlude than dramatic weather, and daylight will slip away early.

Dress for patience: a light waterproof over warm layers, shoes that don’t mind puddles, and an umbrella you can fold away between spits. It’s a good time to run a few errands while the rain eases, take a short, brisk loop through the park to stretch the legs, then reward yourself with a café window seat and a book. If you stay home, let the kettle do its work and tackle a small project, the kind that makes the room feel a shade brighter when you’re done.
